posts.post_content: Now this is what Cipher SHOULD have been. Incremental, subtle advantage that accrues and manipulates the game in ways the opponent wouldn't necessarily realize at first. This can give the Cipher'd creature effectively vigilance, it can untap your lands for the next main phase or the opponent's turn (always dandy for Blue), and it can screw over an opponent's potential counterspells. Target a Plains while someone has a [Sphinx's Revelation](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sphinx's Revelation) in hand and you've basically forced them to cast it in response or wait another turn for it. Definitely a very handy card to have around.
posts.html:

Target a Plains while someone has a Sphinx's Revelation in hand and you've basically forced them to cast it in response or wait another turn for it. Definitely a very handy card to have around.

posts.post_content:
The more I look at this card the more it becomes my favorite card in the set.   
First, when compared to [Hands of Binding](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Hands of Binding) this card fairs better in a vs Control match-up since more often then not you'll be hitting lands with this (don't try to tap opponents' creatures unless you need to stop them from blocking. If they have a tap effect they can tap them in response plus they will untap during their controller's next untap step) letting you avoid a counter spell or hitting your own lands to be able to counter them next turn.  
Second, it is 'free" when you cast it (Untap your lands you used to cast it) then it "gives" you 2 more mana every turn if you can deal damage. This lets you set up your side of the board quicker, as well as allowing you to play Sorcery spells over instants. (See [Pilfered Plans](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Pilfered Plans) over [Inspiration](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Inspiration) since you'll still have your mana to respond to an opponent.  
More so, you can use it late game with something li... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

posts.post_content:
[Goblin Electromancer](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Goblin Electromancer)  
  
T3: Tap all lands for 3 mana, pay 1 for this. Mana pool contains 2 mana now. After resolving, tap the two untapped lands and you have 4 mana total. If you happened to cipher this onto [Tormented Soul](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Tormented Soul), then you've got a total of 6.   
  
Not too shabby for Grixis control... And your next instant or sorcery is going to cost less due to Electromancer. With some shocks you could have... I don't know, [Rakdos's Return](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rakdos's Return) T3 for 5? xD

posts.post_content:
So so so good with counterspells and cheap flyers. You use this early game on a cheap flyer and basically keep your mana open. If the opponent taps out you can play your 2-drop or 3-drop, attack, and leave your mana open for counterspells; if they don't tap out you can instead tap their lands down and drop a cheaper creature (to still leave mana open for a counterspells, bounces, or kill spells.)  
  
Delver with this is proves to be amazing bit of synergy:  
T1 - [Delver of Secrets](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Delver of Secrets)  
T2 - 3 in the air [Hidden Strings](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Hidden Strings), Untap your lands, prepare to [Counterspell](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Counterspell)/[Mana Leak](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mana Leak)  
T3 - [Serendib Efreet](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Serendib Efreet), 3 in the air, untap your lands and prepare as you did last turn  
T4 - 6+ in the air  
  
Consider T4 Nameless inversion to bring the total up to 15 damage. If you've [vapor snag](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=vapor snag)ged or [countersquall](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=countersquall)ed, or [psychic barrier](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=psychic barrier)ed then you can [Psio](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Psio)... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

posts.post_content: Nothing quite like using Hidden Strings to untap the lands used to play it, only to use them to again cast hidden strings and untap the lands on an [Invisible Stalker](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Invisible Stalker) then attack and cast them on [Chronic Flooding](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Chronic Flooding) or [Contaminated Ground](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Contaminated Ground)s enchanted lands. Great way to power multiply that pesky 1/1 and it's fast enough that most decks are still trying to get a basic board presence by the time you're swinging for five or more.

posts.post_content: This card is really fun to use, especially in limited. It's the sort of card that works really well in some scenarios, but it does fail if your creatures have no evasion. I realized how little affect this actually has on your opponents creatures. They don't tap until after your creature has dealt damage, so this basically acts like a nice bonus instead of a tapping spell.
posts.html:
